thermosteam.properties.acentric.acentric_factor_LK(CASRN, Tb=None, Tc=None, Pc=None)[source]Â¶

Estimate the acentric factor of a fluid using a correlation in 5. Return None if acentric factor cannot be estimated.

Parameters

  • CASRN (str) â CASRN for retrieving Tb, Tc, and Pc.

  • Tb (float, optional) â Boiling temperature of the fluid [K]

  • Tc (float, optional) â Critical temperature of the fluid [K]

  • Pc (float, optional) â Critical pressure of the fluid [Pa]

Notes

Internal units are atmosphere and Kelvin. The correlation is as follows:

\[\omega = \frac{\ln P_{br}^{sat} - 5.92714 + 6.09648/T_{br} + 1.28862 \ln T_{br} -0.169347T_{br}^6} {15.2518 - 15.6875/T_{br} - 13.4721 \ln T_{br} + 0.43577 T_{br}^6}\]

Examples

Example value for Isopropylbenzene from Reid (1987):

>>> acentric_factor_LK(425.6, 631.1, 32.1E5)
0.32544249926397856

Using ASPEN V8.4, LK method gives 0.325595.

thermosteam.properties.acentric.acentric_factor(CASRN, Tb=None, Tc=None, Pc=None, Psat=None, method='Any')[source]Â¶

Retrieve the acentric factor of a chemical, omega, or calculate it from correlations or directly through the definition of acentric factor, if possible. Requires a known boiling point, critical temperature and pressure for use of the correlations. Requires accurate vapor pressure data for direct calculation.

Will automatically select a method to use if no method is provided; returns None if the data is not available and cannot be calculated.

Examples

>>> acentric_factor(CASRN='64-17-5')
0.635
Parameters

CASRN (str) â

Returns

omega â Acentric factor of the fluid [-].

Return type

float or dict(str-float)

Other Parameters

  • method (string, optional) â The method name to use. Accepted methods are âPSRKâ, âPDâ, âYawsâ, âLKâ, and âDEFINITIONâ. If method is âAnyâ, the first available value from these methods will returned. If method is âAllâ, a dictionary of method results will be returned.

  • Tb (float, optional) â Boiling temperature of the fluid [K]

  • Tc (float, optional) â Critical temperature of the fluid [K]

  • Pc (float, optional) â Critical pressure of the fluid [Pa]

  • Psat (function(T), optional) â Model to calculate vapor pressure [Pa].

Notes

A total of five sources are available for this function. They are:

  • âPSRKâ, a compillation of experimental and estimated data published in the Appendix of [2]_, the fourth revision of the PSRK model.

  • âPDâ, an older compillation of data published in (Passut & Danner, 1973) 3.

  • âYawsâ, a large compillation of data from a variety of sources; no data points are sourced in the work of 4.

  • âLKâ, a estimation method for hydrocarbons 5.

  • âDEFINITIONâ, based on the definition of omega as presented in [1]_, using vapor pressure data.

See also

acentric_factor_LK(), acentric_factor_DEFINITION()

thermosteam.properties.acentric.Stiel_Polar(CASRN, Tc=None, Pc=None, omega=None, Psat=None)[source]Â¶

Return the Stiel Polar factor of a chemical through the definition of Stiel-polar factor if possible.

Parameters

  • CASRN (string) â

  • Tc (float, optional) â Critical temperature of fluid [K].

  • Pc (float, optional) â Critical pressure of fluid [Pa].

  • omega (float, optional) â Acentric factor of the fluid [-]

  • Psat (function(T)) â Vapor pressure model [Pa].

Returns

factor â Stiel polar factor of compound

Return type

float

Notes

The Stiel Polar factor as presented in [1]_ is given by:

\[x = \log P_r|_{T_r=0.6} + 1.70 \omega + 1.552\]

A few points have also been published in [2]_, which may be used for comparison. Currently this is only used for a surface tension correlation.

Examples

>>> Stiel_Polar(647.3, 22048321.0, 0.344, CASRN='7732-18-5')
0.024581140348734376

1

Halm, Roland L., and Leonard I. Stiel. âA Fourth Parameter for the Vapor Pressure and Entropy of Vaporization of Polar Fluids.â AIChE Journal 13, no. 2 (1967): 351-355. doi:10.1002/aic.690130228.

2

D, Kukoljac MiloÅ¡, and GrozdaniÄ DuÅ¡an K. âNew Values of the Polarity Factor.â Journal of the Serbian Chemical Society 65, no. 12 (January 1, 2000). http://www.shd.org.rs/JSCS/Vol65/No12-Pdf/JSCS12-07.pdf
